ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge of site unknown, design-thinking skills, curatorial skills, and spatial analysis tools.

Skills: Research, Indesign, Photoshop, a lot of indesign programs and this is a great class to get familiar with them,
Knowledge: Really interesting depending on how invested you are with what you research for class.n 
Insights: Diving into the story behind urban architecture, what it means to be urban, and expanding your own narrative.
Learned how to use photoshop, illustrator, Indesign, and more tools to create collages, maps, and layouts.

Learned about different ways of looking at, analyzing, and visually representing spaces, especially those that may not initially seem to be tied to urban processes. In terms of hard skills, I really improved my proficiency with Adobe products, learned how to craft a narrative, and to have a better workflow.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Interesting course material but I think having a bit more structure would have been beneficial to help guide and ground our research. Felt a little overwhelmed / lost / uninspired sometime with translating all my research into succinct visual material.

Strengths: Class trip, you learn so much from the trip as well as get inspired. Good organization.
Weakness: Not a lot of guidance for building your story.
Strengths: student-driven, the student puts as much work into their projects as they would like to and receive good feedback if the student is missing any info

A lot of the work in the class centered around making a visual argument but there was rarely if ever an instructional component for articulating something that way. There needs to be more technique instruction.

I loved this course. Professor Hsiang was very flexible, and was kind and caring when it came to the assignments and ensuring that each student was doing the best exploration of their site that they could. She gave us a lot of creative space to explore our interests and to show off our own analytical and methodical interests through each assignment, and along with the TAs, created an environment in which all students and the teaching team were able to bond. The only weakness was that the two-hour section on Wednesdays was ill-defined at first, but once we became a tight-knit team, it became a great collaborative working space.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would if you are interested in big questions and ideas surrounding urbanization.
Yes, it is a great urban lab. I genuinely enjoyed my projects and loved the TAs.
Yes! Best course I've taken at Yale!
Yes, if you have time to commit yourself to this class then itll become something that will widen your horizons on how the world works.

Yes. The course was challenging, to say the least, but Professor Hsiang and the TAs were extremely clear with their feedback and were committed to seeing you improve within and between each assignment. I'd never felt so supported in a creative exploration, especially considering this was an exploration of a site unknown, and the camaraderie in this class has been unmatched by any other course. The class trip was a huge highlight, and made it clear how the analysis we were doing in the lab connected to real-life problems.

extras.title: ARCH 360 01/URBN 360 01 - Urban Lab: An Urban World
